review.title: A Parallel Corpus of Translationese
review.abstract: We describe bilingual English-French and English-German parallel corpora in which the direction of translation is accurately and reliably annotated. The corpus is diverse, consisting of parliamentary proceedings, literary works, transcripts of TED talks and political commentary. It will be instrumental for research of translationese and its applications to (human and machine) translation; specifically, it can be used for the task of translationese identification, a research direction that enjoys a growing interest in recent years. To evaluate the quality of the corpus, we replicate and expand on previous results of supervised identification of translationese, and further extend the experiments to additional datasets, including an additional language pair, and exploiting bilingual information.
histories: the paper is under a journal review

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: In order to preserve the quality of water, we must abide by the rules we have set ourselves.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Identification of translationese using monolingual (English) corpora
sections.text: We first reproduced the classification results of Volansky et al. (2015) on the English-English-translated-from-the-French Europarl dataset, using the feature sets detailed in Section 4.2. Furthermore, we present results for three further English-French datasets, as well as for the English-German corpus. Tables 3 and 4 report on the tenfold cross-validation classification. The EUR * column refers to the classification results of Europarl, as reported by Volansky et al. (2015). Although they experimented with a slightly different setup, we detail these results in Table 3 for illustrative comparison. In line with previous work, the classification results are very high, resulting in near-perfect precision for most feature sets (with a single exception of coherent markers, some of which can be attributed to their smaller dimension).

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Identification of translationese using bilingual English-French corpus
sections.text: So far, we have demonstrated the usefulness of our corpus for classifying original texts versus translated texts using monolingual English data sets. However, our corpus is parallel - this facilitates the use of additional information for the task of identifying the translation system; that is, the decision on the status of a translation of a piece of text can be based on both the English side and its French (or German) counterpart. In the next experiment, we use the bilingual Europarl data set by generating an extended feature set based on the frequencies of the English functional words (extracted from the English chunk) and frequencies of the French functional words 14 extracted from the corresponding French chunk. Overall, for a parallel English text, we come up to about 900 feature values. We use the same classifier as specified in Section 4.1 and rate it with ten-fold cross-references (Figure 3 shows the accuracy of the classification based on bilingual information).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: This work presents several parallel bilingual English-French and English-German corpora with precise direction of translation. To evaluate the quality of the corpus, we have replicated and expanded several previous results of the supervised identification of the translation system, and expanded the experiments to include additional sets of data, including an additional language pair and the use of bilingual information. The potential value of these records stimulates further corpus development and exploration activities. Our future plans include the expansion of the corpus to include additional language pairs (especially English-Hebrew). We also intend to advance the identification of the translation system by reducing the size of logical units (chunks) that are subject to classification, and finally a single sentence pair.It has been shown in a series of works (Kurokawa et al., 2009; Lembersky et al., 2013, 2011, bilingb; Twitto-Shmuel, 2015) that awareness of this translation work can be used in a more positive way.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank Noam Ordan for much advice and encouragement. We also thank Sergiu Nisioi for helpful suggestions. We thank Philipp Koehn for providing the Europarl corpus; Cyril Goutte, George Foster and Pierre Isabelle for providing an annotated version of the Hansard corpus; Franc ois Yvon and Andra's Farkas15 for providing their literary corpus; and the TED OTP team for sharing TED lectures and translations. We also thank Raphael Salkie for providing his diverse English-German corpus.15 http: / / farkastranslations.com, accessed in August 2015.

For example, Koppel and Ordan (2011) showed that while the overall accuracy of their translationese identification classifiers is near-perfect, when a classifier is trained on translations from one language, but is tested on translations from a different language, accuracy drops significantly.

For example, Koppel and Ordan (2011) showed that while the overall accuracy of their translationese identification classifiers is near-perfect, when a classifier is trained on translations from one language, but is tested on translations from a different language, accuracy drops significantly. Popescu (2011) demonstrated that a classifier, trained to discriminate between original British literature and English literature translated from French, failed to predict translation status of English literature written by American authors and translations from German.

For example, Koppel and Ordan (2011) showed that while the overall accuracy of their translationese identification classifiers is near-perfect, when a classifier is trained on translations from one language, but is tested on translations from a different language, accuracy drops significantly. Popescu (2011) demonstrated that a classifier, trained to discriminate between original British literature and English literature translated from French, failed to predict translation status of English literature written by American authors and translations from German. Avner et al. (Forthcoming) reported that while they were able to identify translationese with high accuracy within a given corpus (literary texts in Hebrew and Hebrew-translated-from-English), the classification was much less accurate when either the genre of the texts was modified (popular science vs. literature) or the source language was changed (French instead of English). Similar trends were noted by Rabinovich and Wintner (2015), showing a dra-
The entire corpus is freely available; some subsets have already been used in a pilot study on unsupervised identification of translationese (Rabinovich and Wintner, 2015).

The Europarl sub-corpus is extracted from the collection of the proceedings of the European Parliament, dating back to 1996, originally collected by Koehn (2005). The original Europarl corpus is organized as several language-pairs, each with multiple sentence-aligned files.
Mainly due to its multilingual nature, however, Europarl has been used extensively in SMT (Koehn et al., 2009) and in cross-lingual research (Cartoni et al.

, 2009) and in cross-lingual research (Cartoni et al., 2013). It has even been adapted specifically for research in translation studies: Islam and Mehler (2012) compiled a customized version of Europarl, where the direction of translation is indicated.

It has even been adapted specifically for research in translation studies: Islam and Mehler (2012) compiled a customized version of Europarl, where the direction of translation is indicated. They used meta-data from the corpus, and in particular the language tag, to identify the original language in which each sentence was spoken, and removed sentence pairs for which this information was missing. A similar strategy was used by Lembersky et al. (2012b) and Cartoni and Meyer (2012).

It has even been adapted specifically for research in translation studies: Islam and Mehler (2012) compiled a customized version of Europarl, where the direction of translation is indicated. They used meta-data from the corpus, and in particular the language tag, to identify the original language in which each sentence was spoken, and removed sentence pairs for which this information was missing. A similar strategy was used by Lembersky et al. (2012b) and Cartoni and Meyer (2012). We now detail how we extracted reliable speaker identities from Europarl texts.

This corpus most likely suffers from similar problems as the Europarl corpus discussed above; indeed, Mollin (2007), who investigated the British Hansard parliamentary transcripts, found that “the transcripts omit performance characteristics of spoken language, such as incomplete utterances or hesitations, as well as any type of extrafactual, contextual talk” and that “transcribers and editors also alter speakers’ lexical and grammatical choices towards more conservative and formal variants.

To validate the quality of the corpus we replicated the experiments of Volansky et al. (2015), who conducted a thorough exploration of supervised classification of translationese, using dozens of feature types.

To validate the quality of the corpus we replicated the experiments of Volansky et al. (2015) only used the Europarl corpus (in its original format) and worked on English translated from French, we extended the experiments to all the datasets described above, including also English translated from German.
For part of speech tagging, we employ the Stanford implementation along with its models for French and English (Manning et al., 2014).

metadata.abstractText: We describe bilingual English–French and English–German parallel corpora in which the direction of translation is accurately and reliably annotated. The corpus is diverse, consisting of parliamentary proceedings, literary works, transcripts of TED talks and political commentary. It will be instrumental for research of translationese and its applications to (human and machine) translation; specifically, it can be used for the task of translationese identification, a research direction that enjoys a growing interest in recent years. To evaluate the quality of the corpus, we replicate and expand on previous results of supervised identification of translationese, and further extend the experiments to additional datasets, including an additional language pair, and exploiting bilingual information.
